captions.text:
Finally, the long-awaited sequel to Obsidian&#39;s 
smash hit The Outer Worlds that gamers have been

screaming for, creatively titled The Outer Worlds 
2, has landed, and—well, I say long awaited;

it doesn&#39;t feel like that much time has 
passed since it was announced. But it is—well,

I say smash hit; it more sort of plopped 
onto the release schedule a few years back,

and I&#39;d have forgotten about it faster if I didn&#39;t 
keep getting it confused with Outer Wilds. A—and

I say gamers have been screaming for it; we&#39;ve 
more been asking matter of factly if Obsidian were

planning to do a sequel with the uncomfortable 
air of a concerned parent when their 20-something

son expresses an interest in crypto. But for what 
it&#39;s worth, here it is. The Outer Worlds 2. Also,

I say creatively titled; they just stuck 
a 2 on the end, but hey, at least that&#39;s

informative. It&#39;s The Outer Worlds plus another 
one. And that pretty much tells you exactly what

you should expect in regards to new ideas and 
innovation and all that hard-to-quantify shit

us tiresome people keep going on about. Oh, and 
I say it landed; it&#39;s largely been another plop

situation like a blind baby kitten questing for 
its mum&#39;s nipple and falling off the back steps.

So, we return to the satirical sci-fi 
retro-futurist dystopian setting of

The Outer Worlds 1 in which future corporations 
have cunningly escaped government regulation by

jetting off to deep space and founding their own 
colonies far from the grasp of occupational health

and safety inspectors. In Outer Worlds 2, we play 
an agent of the Earth government tasked to head

out into a strategically important star system 
that&#39;s being buggered from both ends by an evil,

oppressive corporation in hole 1 and a weird, 
pseudo-religious science cult in hole 2. So, as a

sort of galactic pulp space hero equivalent of an 
efficiency consultant, we go in, get liberatin&#39;,

maybe pick a side, maybe broker peace between the 
two factions so they can both equally enjoy the

benefits of hole 1 with just a small rearrangement 
of penises. But of course, things don&#39;t turn out

as simple as that: there&#39;s a betrayal, your team 
get killed, obviously there&#39;s a third faction who

the other two both hate &#39;cause there&#39;s got to be 
someone you can uncomplicatedly gun down whenever

some kind of token action gameplay is called for 
and you can&#39;t just shoot angry wildlife the whole

time; I got over my searing hatred for purple 
monsters when they cancelled Barney the Dinosaur.

And there&#39;s one of those weird galaxy-destroying 
space phenomena starting to happen that the crew

of the Enterprise were always dealing 
with, but there&#39;s no Enterprise here,

just you and your complete lack of spiffy 
uniforms. I need to be honest up front, listeners:

I am really struggling with this review, and 
not just because my dog keeps trying to lick the

remnants of smokey bacon crisps out of my laptop 
keyboard. I certainly don&#39;t think Outer Worlds 2

is a bad game in terms of design, gameplay loops, 
or dialogue writing, but there&#39;s something so

quintessentially unstimulating about it that I 
can&#39;t quite put my finger on. It might be that

the overall threat we&#39;re up against is so vague. 
There&#39;s a wibbly wobbly thing in space that might

kill us all but doesn&#39;t seem to be getting much 
of a wriggle on, so don&#39;t sweat it. The faction

interplay is about as predictable as these things 
get. It&#39;s not quite fascists versus nutters;

it&#39;s more like soul-crushing ultra-capitalist 
libertarian fascists versus pseudo-rationalist

socialist cultist nutters, and both sides have 
nuanced takes on the question of freedom versus

stability, but ultimately, that means 
it doesn&#39;t matter which one you side

with as they have equal military might and both 
spout absolute fucking nonsense when pressed on

philosophy and will cheerfully change their minds 
completely if you pass the right speech checks.

Speaking of, the roleplaying aspect consists 
of a list of skills to pick from that all have

equal prominence despite their huge variance in 
usefulness. You need at least one combat skill;

fuckin&#39; Barney isn&#39;t going to be impressed by 
your 14 points in science, and the only one

worth taking is guns &#39;cause NPCs usually have 
guns, and why don&#39;t you ask a veteran how much

good all those press-ups did them when they 
were up against Vietnamese snipers? Besides

the straight combat skills, sneaking can 
also be handy, but basically every other

skill is only useful for speech checks. Even 
engineering and hacking comes down to speech

checks because it&#39;s presented as you having 
lively conversations with vending machines,

and there&#39;s not much point in diversifying 
because you only get one or two points per

level and it doesn&#39;t take long for the speech 
checks of eight or nine to start cropping up.

There&#39;s no way to prepare or anticipate what 
skills are going to come up in the speech checks,

so this is essentially random. You go 
through the cycle of talking to people,

sneaking around offices, and shooting dudes and 
are occasionally permitted to sidestep a sneak

around or shooting session because a preceding 
conversation happened to contain a check for

one of the skills you arbitrarily chose to pump 
points into. Like one specific dude is supposed

to be a boss fight but you&#39;re able to talk them 
down through your shared interest in knitting.

Perhaps that&#39;s why I find myself so turgidly 
lukewarm on Outer Worlds 2. As I said, I can&#39;t

really fault the essentials. The shooting and the 
stealthing certainly seems to be a touch improved

on the last game &#39;cause the NPC party members 
are better at keeping their mouths shut, if not

surviving any gunfight that goes on longer than 
12 seconds. The sticking point is in the broader

questions of the story. Like, what the fuck are we 
even trying to achieve and why should we care? I

mean, the whole business with the all-destroying 
wibbly wobbly space anomaly we forget about for

the entire first half of the game while we pursue 
the person who betrayed us from one planet to

another so that we can ultimately talk them out of 
a boss fight through our shared interest in llama

husbandry. It&#39;s possible the Douglas Adams-esque 
satirical tone is making it unclear what we&#39;re

supposed to be taking seriously. Like half the 
NPCs you run into are satirical caricatures

of middle managers or scientists or whatever, 
and when they get their legs bitten off field

testing their new toothbrushes for green space 
tigers, we&#39;re supposed to point and laugh. But

then your NPC party members, who I wouldn&#39;t have 
picked from any other NPC in a lineup because,

as before, they just seem to be random dudes 
who invite themselves aboard, they all have the

inevitable RPG party member tragic backstories, 
and THOSE we&#39;re supposed to give a shit about?

&quot;Oh captain, I just can&#39;t get over the fact that 
a green space tiger bit the legs off my beloved

mentor; please pursue vengeance across space on 
my behalf.&quot; So the headline is I can&#39;t connect

to Outer Worlds 2 on a narrative level and the 
gameplay isn&#39;t doing anything interesting enough

to compensate. I described the first game as being 
basically Fallout in space, but on reflection,

the watchword of Fallout games was always, &quot;Hey, 
do the plot or just pick a direction and walk;

you&#39;ll probably run into something to do.&quot; And 
that really doesn&#39;t apply to the paltry little

mini-sandboxes that represent the different 
planets we can visit in Outer Worlds, nicely

realized with their alien-esque color schemes 
though they are; if you pick a direction and walk,

you&#39;re more likely to break your nose on the rocky 
barriers designed to keep you on the predetermined

paths that the provided maps seem to be weirdly 
noncommittal about. The question I keep coming

back to is, &quot;Does a game benefit from being set 
in space when you&#39;re never actually in space,

just fast travelling between planets? 
Wouldn&#39;t the game functionally be the

same if every planet was, say, a level of 
the same multistory car park?&quot; Probably,

except we&#39;d be avenging mentors getting 
their legs bitten off by green space Priuses.
